body: Made requested code changes.  Thanks for all the help.
I merged with what was in the upstream master branch.  That is how those unrelated changes got in.  I don't recall editing those unrelated  files.

> I merged with what was in the upstream master branch.

Personally, I try to avoid rebasing or merging master into a branch/PR that is under review because I think it makes it harder for the reviewer to follow whats going on.  Sometimes its necessary though.  

In this case I am mystified as to what is happening because I thought changes that were already made in master would not show up in the diff.

>  I don't recall editing those unrelated files.

I am not sure how it happened but the files were changed in a commit (e683dd0dbf8e48099b9f7f0e8ad8a80e35a06d98) of yours for this PR.

Since I had been working on this a while I though it would be good to pull the upstream master and merge to the branch so I could work around any changes that someone was making to the files I was working on.  Sorry about the confusion.
I did some rebasing on my branch.  I must have squashed a commit that occurred on upstream/master.

> Since I had been working on this a while I though it would be good to pull the upstream master and merge to the branch so I could work around any changes that someone was making to the files I was working on.

Makes sense.  When I am reviewing I am more than happy to resolve conflicts when merging someones PR.

> Since I had been working on this a while I though it would be good to pull the upstream master and merge to the branch so I could work around any changes that someone was making to the files I was working on. Sorry about the confusion.

In general, if you have something long-lived, it's better to rebase. Merging the branch that contained your merge-base back onto yours frequently creates confusing problems like this. Also, even if you did successfully merge without these kinds of issues, if somebody rebases again later, they'll probably have to re-resolve merge conflicts. So, it doesn't save any work to merge in. Rebase, on the other hand, keeps all the commit history linear in your feature branch, and is less likely to have these kinds of merge artifacts.

I frequently do interactive rebase with long-lived branches (`git rebase -i`)
Would you like me to just re-branch from master and redo all the work?  Its really no problem for me to do that if it will preserve history correctly.
Can you add a default implementation since it is a new method on an existing interface?  Looks good otherwise.

You can just rebase, fix any conflicts, and do a force push, and it will update this PR. If it's easier to reset this branch to the master commit, and add a new commit, and force push that, that'll work, too (effectively the same thing).
Just pushed the branch again.  Let me know if there are any problems.  If there are I will just start over from scratch.  No big deal.

I think you still need to rebase with master.  Follow something like below:
```
git checkout master
git fetch upstream
git pull upstream master
git checkout accumulo-907_
git rebase master
git push -f origin accumulo-907_
```
I will look at this.  Did this work in 1.9?

> I will look at this. Did this work in 1.9?

Yes.  The monitor was rewritten for 2.0 and it just seems to have lost this functionality.

For future reference, the following instructions for rebase are even more succinct:

```bash
git remote update # optionally add --prune to update deleted branches
git checkout accumulo-907_ # if you're not already in that branch locally
git rebase upstream/master # the actual rebase, I recommend doing interactive with -i
git push -f origin accumulo-907_ # to update your fork and the PR
```
Would be nice to make this change for 1.9
I merged this pull request with the commit 61c44919de22c92c98 but I referenced #924 by accident instead of #942 in the commit message.
I accidentally made an unrelated commit 61c44919de22c92c9828 that references this issue. The commit should have referenced #942
tested by running a cluster using kerberos for clients through a 1.7 -> 1.9 upgrade.
Is this for systems which use the KerberosAuthenticator, but with something other than the ZKPermHandler?

It's for the Kerberos configs. The current code has hard coded the user name "root", which is extremely unlikely to be used in a kerberos set up.

the KerberosePermissionHandler base 64 encodes all the principals, so you also can't directly use ZKPermHandler on a non-encoded name (as mentioned in the comments in the code)

Okay, so I knew the Kerberos setup used its own `KerberosAuthenticator`, but for some reason, I misremembered it still using `ZKPermHandler` directly instead of indirectly via `KerberosPermissionHandler`, which wraps it. That was the basis of my confusion. Your fix makes sense to me now. Thanks.

While this change fixes the problem, I think the comment could be improved. I'll update my review with a proposed diff.

Nice catch, Busbey. Thanks for the thorough comments too.

LGTM

I am closing this because I was able to satisfy my use case w/o this information.  All I needed to know was the scans current run time (while is already available in 2.0.0-alpha-2) and using that info I could dispatch long running scans to another executor.   I created the following test while exploring this scenario.

apache/accumulo-testing#56
merged to master in abc19721a
@EdColeman do you think reverting the exists method back to 1.8 behavior is needed?  Or does using the scanner suffice for your use case?
@milleruntime and @ctubbsii I am finished making updates based on the comments that have been made so far.

I think the current behavior should be classified as a bug and not something that should only be handled by documentation.

With that, I think the discussion then becomes how serious a bug is it? Would I consider it a blocker for the next 1.9.x or 2.0 release, maybe not, for 2.1, probably. Because there is a work-around for the "forward" case where the table has been created, but not propagated to the cache, instead of checking for a table exits() and relying on the scanner to fail "works", but it seems like it could be an "expensive" why to check. Especially in cases where the table truly did not exist, but people keep trying to scan anyway.

I do not know how to handle the reverse case where you want to make sure a table has been deleted.

Even if there was a method to clear the cache, you could then test and if you didn't think the answer was what you wanted, clear the cache and retry may be a work-around rather that relying on the scanner behavior.

Do you think reverting the behavior would impact performance of applications that have a relatively static configuration?  Are there ways to use the znode timestamps / ids that could be used to determine if the cache is current?
This supersedes #938

It looks like the build is failing due to error below:
```
[ERROR] java/io/File.<init>(Ljava/io/File;Ljava/lang/String;)V reads a file whose location might be specified by user input [org.apache.accumulo.test.DumpConfigIT, org.apache.accumulo.test.DumpConfigIT] At DumpConfigIT.java:[line 64]At DumpConfigIT.java:[line 64] PATH_TRAVERSAL_IN
```

The tablet server has a thread that continual checks if tablets need compaction or split.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/c7a54c80b937fd606ebdd6b3672f837f65b6258f/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/TabletServer.java#L2175

The master has three really important threads that assign tablets for the root, metadata, and user tablets.  If these threads are not running then tablets will not be assigned.  These threads are all run by TabletGroupWatcher

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/050dec2003a786ea014c994a38e180a82b997c0d/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/TabletGroupWatcher.java#L136

There is currently code that watches compactions and logs a warning if it has not read or written any data in a certain amount of time.  It addition to logging a warning it might be nice to  increment a stuck compaction counter.  Could decrement when unstuck.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/2b9c9275ea5f992cfa2bd1a7e3f8994a41e69df3/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/tablet/CompactionWatcher.java#L31

There is also code that looks stuck tablet loads and logs a warning.   Would also be nice to have a counter for stuck loads.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/b915947c0c22d9db717067b601c62829205d1505/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/TabletServerResourceManager.java#L437

> It looks like the build is failing due to error below:
> 
> ```
> [ERROR] java/io/File.<init>(Ljava/io/File;Ljava/lang/String;)V reads a file whose location might be specified by user input [org.apache.accumulo.test.DumpConfigIT, org.apache.accumulo.test.DumpConfigIT] At DumpConfigIT.java:[line 64]At DumpConfigIT.java:[line 64] PATH_TRAVERSAL_IN
> ```

Hmm, I'll take a look. I didn't see that fail, but I could have missed it. I thought the Travis build was failing due to sec-bugs timing out... which it frequently does in Travis.
Nice PR. Have you tested this?

> Do you think reverting the behavior would impact performance of applications that have a relatively static configuration? 

I believe so.  Applications that took advantage of the performance improvements upgrading to 1.9 (I believe Fluo is one of them) will be impacted by reverting behavior back to 1.8. 

> Are there ways to use the znode timestamps / ids that could be used to determine if the cache is current?

This may be possible by checking the "mtime" on the tables node, which should indicate when a table ID -> name mapping was updated or table added/dropped.  This would require a bit more work though.

I am thinking we may have put ourselves in a situation where we need to create another exists method.  Revert the behavior of the current method to always check zookeeper.  Than add a new method, something like "existsInCache(String tableName, boolean clearCacheOnFail)".  Which will have better performance and the option to clear cache the cache.  @keith-turner thoughts on this?

Yes.  I have tested it.  I have killed my Tserver.  Refreshed the view.  Saw the errors.  Hit the link.  But you have to turn the Tserver back on and do a refresh to see the log messages disappear.  Works well.  Might need more work if that is what folks decide.
After hitting the link you have to F5 the page.   I should be able to do that refresh after the jquery call to clearLogs(). I will look around.
I will work on this now.  Any idea on steps I can make to duplicate this?

> After hitting the link you have to F5 the page. I should be able to do that refresh after the jquery call to clearLogs(). I will look around.

I think that was behavior before (to refresh the page) so it would be nice if you add that back in.
We are all set here now.
Will fix sec-bugs errors next. Merging now to facilitate follow-on issues which might otherwise cause conflicts later.
Deprecating org.apache.accumulo.core.data.TabletId would also effect the Locations interface in o.a.a.core.client.adamin.

> I will work on this now. Any idea on steps I can make to duplicate this?

Could delete a Table's file from HDFS and then try to scan the table in the shell. I think that will trigger something to show here.

After further investigation, it looks like the Zookeeper exception was NoExists (after several connection losses with retries). I can contribute fix I made locally if necessary, however testing it seems like it would be difficult.
Replaced link with the "Boostrap" library button that Christopher asked for.  Will push change shortly.
Pushed the new change.
So I think we do need to have a getServiceEnv() to pass to the user, I am just not sure where to implement it...

Might need to file a bug upstream with exec-maven-plugin? We could also skip this task in the meantime... as I'm not really sure what this test is doing anyway (except forcing the native maps to be built for the ITs, perhaps?).
There appears to be a race condition with the new cache of the table ID name map.  I will close this PR since it doesn't fix the problem.

It appears that this could be a race condition with the changes made in 1.9.  Specifically [here](https://github.com/milleruntime/accumulo/blob/757f62b5a1e2abd6d97d803f5325fdae622167eb/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/clientImpl/Tables.java#L115).
@andrewglowacki  I would be interested in seeing the changes.

It seems on the tablet server the deprecated method currently returns table config.  However the replacement does not offer a way to get this same info because a table id is needed.  One possibly solution to this is to add a getTableId method to IteratorEnv, which would enable the following code.

```java
tableConf = iterEnv.getServiceEnv().getConfiguration(iterEnv.getTableId())
```

> It seems on the tablet server the deprecated method currently returns table config. However the replacement does not offer a way to get this same info because a table id is needed. One possibly solution to this is to add a getTableId method to IteratorEnv, which would enable the following code.
> 
> ```java
> tableConf = iterEnv.getServiceEnv().getConfiguration(iterEnv.getTableId())
> ```

A convenience method on iterEnv might be nice, which does all that more succinctly.
I got on it.  I will repush
Performed a rebase that removed some UI commits from my accumulo-927 branch.  Removed those UI mods and only kept the ones related to this fix for #918.
I will get working on this.
I tested the latest changes and everything works.
This issues was fixed by PR #926

> Did the Objects.nonNull actually compile? Or was that the result of a merge conflict from 1.9's use of Guava's Objects class?

Yes, it compiled but Objects.nonNull only returns boolean and does not throw IllegalArgumentException so it wasn't doing anything.

> Yes, it compiled but Objects.nonNull only returns boolean and does not throw IllegalArgumentException so it wasn't doing anything.

Wow, that's crazy. The names are so similar. This is a mistake that is likely going to happen a lot. We should probably use checkstyle or something else to ban this method, unless it is used as a predicate, such as `.filter(Objects::nonNull)`.

You have to break out of the while loop to stop calling pool.getAnyTransport and also stop printing out log messages.  Since we govern the amount of log messages we should stop filling up the disk.  You will still see plenty of messages in the logs.
I have to shorten the log message.  The style checker doesn't like that.

The main problem isn't the infinite set of log messages... the main problem is that the test enters some failure state, and never exits that state. Yes, suppressing the log message will help not fill up disk... but it's also not a solution to the underlying problem of the test never realizing it's in a failure state and continuing forever.
I totally agree with you Christopher.  I am really just checking this in as an interim fix.  I should have made that clear.
I'll give it a try tomorrow.  Your code is in the vein of what I am trying to do but a better solution.  Thanks.
I implemented Mike's recommendation.

I am running ITs now but other than that, I think this is good to go.  With this, the org.apache.accumulo.core.iterators package is close to being public API.  @keith-turner @ctubbsii any more feedback?
Works for all the links on the page. Now.

> This is okay. It exposes something which is currently being used, but as public API. However, I think it might be better if we simply expose something like `addEnvironment(key, value)`, so it's a bit more future-proof. Then, the user can set the `CLASSPATH` environment variable when mini launches processes, but they can also set things like `USER` and `HOME` and `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, and others, as needed.

I think this is an interesting idea that could be explored in a future issue.
Looking into this now.
All ITs are passing on this PR
Sorry for the delay on this. I was tasked with some time sensitive tasks that prevented me from focusing on this.

No worries.  This was just an idea that I thought would be straight forward but turns out wasn't really.  I won't be offended if you close the PR :smile:
Closing in favor of #973
This is ready for review for now. I'd like to merge this in as a checkpoint towards further upgrading htrace to 4.1. This gets us to 3.2, with a bunch of other reliability improvements.

haha, @mikewalch is too fast
There are checks and test for the checks to ensure that the set of files in a load plan equals the set of files in the dir.

@keith-turner Does your previous comment mean no work is done, or is necessary? If so, we should remove the 2.0 label.
How were you seeing those warnings?  I was getting 0 warnings in IntelliJ.

> HTrace has been retired. I am not sure how well the newer supported Java. Is this worth the effort? Could move to Zipkin or Opentracing

I've looked into Opentracing. I don't think it's mature enough at this point. I would prefer to unretire the HTrace project, have it graduate, and add opentracing compatibility to it. For now, it is worth the effort to get in line with what Hadoop 3 is using... which is 4.1.0-incubating. However, getting to 3.2 was aa major checkpoint towards that.

> How were you seeing those warnings? I was getting 0 warnings in IntelliJ.

Command-line from the OpenJDK compiler, during maven-compiler-plugin execution (also in Eclipse, if I set the option to do so).  (BTW, the correct fix for handling deprecated overrides, is to also deprecate--rather than suppress--wherever a deprecated interface method is overridden, unless the intention is to deprecate only from the interface, and leave the subclass implementation un-deprecated, but that's unusual.)
Looking further at the impl of CryptoOutputStream, it seems like its OK to keep it as is.
Not an issue.

I did a few experiments with 1.9.3-SNAPSHOT and did not see any issues.  I tried different combinations of disabling walogs, enabling walogs, writing data, and killing tservers.  The tablets always recovered without issue.
